responses.content: During the quarter, we saw improvement in many of our key operational metrics, including in-stock levels and delivery speed and saw a subsequent step-up in consumer demand. For the quarter, worldwide net sales of $121.2 billion exceeded the top end of our revenue guidance range and represented an increase of 10% year-over-year, excluding approximately 320 basis points of unfavorable impact from changes in foreign exchange rates. This was a larger foreign exchange headwind than the 200 basis point impact we had incorporated into our Q2 guidance.

Our revenue growth accelerated to over 40% growth from the period between May 2020 and May 2021. While demand has remained strong, the lapping of this high growth period depressed our revenue growth rate for the following 12 months ending in May of this year. Our growth rates going forward will no longer require this historical explanation.

Prime members have meaningfully increased their spend since the start of the pandemic. We continue to improve the customer experience in Q2, including quarter-over-quarter improvements in delivery speed and inventory in-stock levels. Our Prime membership program remains a key driver of our worldwide stores business.
We reported an overall net loss of $2 billion in the second quarter, which includes a pretax valuation loss of $3.9 billion from our investment in Rivian Automotive.

AWS saw net sales of $19.7 billion in Q2, up 33% year-over-year, reaching an annualized sales run rate of nearly $79 billion. AWS continues to grow at a fast pace, and we believe we are still in the early stages of enterprise and public sector adoption of the cloud.

For full-year 2022, we expect to spend slightly more on capital investments than last year, with a shift in the proportion of capital spending among our businesses. Technology infrastructure spend is expected to grow year-over-year to support AWS innovation.

Our Q3 guidance includes an estimated approximately 390 basis points of unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates. The third quarter operating income guidance range is zero to $3.5 billion.
We started making customer deliveries using Rivian electric delivery vehicles and provided our third quarter financial guidance as part of our earnings release.

Advertising revenue was up 25% year-over-year, demonstrating a strong run rate compared to overall revenue growth. We're pleased with the performance of our advertising team and the value it provides to sellers and vendors.

Our grocery formats, including Go Grocery and Amazon Fresh, are performing well with increasing customer interest. We continue to innovate with self-checkout capabilities and Just Walk Out technology, enhancing convenience and efficiency for our customers.

We recently hosted Amazon Accelerate, introducing new tools and capabilities for selling partners, including local selling options and global selling tools to facilitate U.S. third-party sellers expanding their offerings worldwide.

Our AWS backlog has grown significantly, reaching $88.9 billion as of March, up 68% year-over-year, with a weighted average remaining term of 3.8 years. This reflects continued strong demand and long-term commitments from our customers.

questions: You mentioned the bridge from Q2 to Q3 EBIT guidance, including a $1.5 billion operational improvement and increased costs in AWS. Where are the other areas where you're investing more to grow, and is any of that associated with merchandise margin or step-ups in discounting?
Regarding the fulfillment and transportation CapEx looking into the fourth quarter and next year, how far ahead have you planned for these builds over the last nine months?
Are AWS booking rates experiencing a slowdown as customers take longer to work through deal terms and durations?
With AWS margins dropping from 35% in Q1 to 29% in Q2, what factors should we consider going forward, especially regarding decreasing server life benefits and the tougher macro environment?
Can you provide an update on how much of the advertising services line is driven by North America e-commerce versus international e-commerce, and the relative growth rates between these regions?
How are you positioning and investing in areas like Connected TV and programmatic advertising, and what implications do these investments have for your advertising business?
Can you discuss your focus on increasing the third-party mix and how that fits into plans for improved efficiency?
Regarding international operations, how much of the sequential margin weakness was driven by foreign exchange?
How did the price action you took on Prime and merchant fees impact retention during the quarter, and is this sufficient to offset the inflationary pressures?
Regarding the Buy with Prime initiative, how do you see its rollout from being invitation-only to being available to all merchants using FBA, and what are the broader implications for the business?
With the quarter-on-quarter decline in headcount and the upcoming holiday season, how do you plan to manage headcount additions?

Stock-based compensation came in below your guidance for the second quarter. Is this due to not meeting hiring goals, or is the environment for hiring technical and engineering talent becoming more challenging?
